Here bigynneth Somer Soneday.
Opon a somer soneday se I þe sonne,
Erly risinde in þe est ende;
Day daweþ over doune, derknes is donne,
I warp on my wedes, to wode wolde I wende.
Wiþ kenettes kene, that wel couþe criez conne,
I hiede to holte, wiþ honteres hende;
So ryfly on rugge roon and raches ronne,
Þat in launde vnder lynde me leste to lende,
And lenede;
Kenettes questede to quelle,
Al so breme so any belle,
Þe deer daunceden in þe delle,
Þat al þe downe denede.
Denede dale and downe, for dryft of þe deer in drede,
For meche murþe of mouþ þe murie moeth made;
I ros, and romede, and sey roon raches to &yogh;ede,
Þey stalken vnder schawe, schatereden in schade.
And lordes lenged, and ladies leces to-lede,
Wiþ griþle grehoundes gode to game and glade;
And I cam to þe game, þer gromes gonne grede,
And at a water wilde I wende ouer han wade,
Þer was;
I stalked be þe strem and be þe strond,
Fer I be þe flod fond,
A bot doun be a lond,
So passed I þe pas.
So passede I þe pas, priuely to pleye,
And ferde forþ in that frith, folk forto fynde;
Lawly longe I lustnede, and vnder lowe lay,
Þat I ne herde hond, horn, hunte, hert, ne hynde.
So wyde I walkede, þat I wax wery of þe wey,
Þanne les I my layk, and lenede under lynde;
And als I sat be side, I say soþ for to sey,
A wifman wiþ a wonder whel weue with þe wynde,
And wond;
Opon þe whel were I wene,
Merye men and madde i-mene,
To hire I gan gon in grene,
And fortune Y fond.
Fortune frend and fo, fayrest fere,
Ferli fals fikel to fonde is i-founde;
Þe whel &yogh;e torneþ to wo, fro wo into wele þat were,
In the ronynge rynge of þe roe, that renneþ so rounde.
A lok of þat leuedy, wiþ lovelich lere,
Mi gode gameliche game gurte to grounde;
Couþe I carpe carpying, creftly and clere.
Of þat birde bastons in bale me bounde,
Ful bowne;
Naþeles, ne mene I nat nay,
I wile, ar I wende away,
Redy resons in a ray,
Radely to rowne.
Redely to roune rounes to rede,
A loueloker leuedi liuiþ non in lond;
I wolde han went wiþ þat whyt, in worþlich wede,
So ferly fair of face, to fore hire I fond.
Þe gold of hire gurdel gloud as a glede,
Þat blisful burde in bale me bond;
Of hire ly&yogh;thhed in herte I hadde hede,
And wiþ a wonderful whel that worþi wyth wond,
Wyþ mayn;
A wifman of so much my&yogh;th,
So wonder a whelwry&yogh;th,
Sey I neuere with sy&yogh;th,
Soth forto seyn.
Soþ to seye, sitte I sey, as my sic&yogh;the sente,
A begyngge gome, gameliche gay;
Bry&yogh;t as the blostme, with browes i-bente,
On þe whel þat þe wy&yogh;th weuede in þe wey,
Wyterly him was wel, whan þe whel wente,
For he layked and low, lenyng als he lay;
Loueliche lokyngges þe loueli me lente,
A meriere man on molde, monen I ne may,
In mynde;
Þe gome I gaf a gretyng,
He seyde, ‘Sestou, swetyng,
Þe crowne of þat comely Kyng,
I cleyme be kynde.’
‘Be kynde it me come
to cleyme kyngene kyngdom,
Kyngdom be kynde
to me, þe whel wile wynde;
Wynd wel, worþliche wy&yogh;th,
fare fortune, frendene fly&yogh;th,
Flitte forþ, fly&yogh;tte,
on þe selue sete to sitte.’
‘Sitte, I say, and seþe on a semeli sete,
Ry&yogh;th on þe rounde, on þe rennyng ryng;
Caste kne ouer kne, as a kyng kete,
Comely cloþed in a cope, crouned as a kyng.’
Hey herte hadde he, of hastif hete,
He leyde his leg opon liþ at his likyng;
Ful loþ were þe lordyng his lordschipe lete;
He wende al the world were at his weldyng,
Ful wy&yogh;th;
On knes I kyþed þat kyng,
He seyde, ‘sestou, sweting,
How I regne wiþ ring,
Richest in ry&yogh;th?’
‘Richest in ry&yogh;th, quen and knyth,
kyng conne me calle,
Mest man of my&yogh;th,
fair folk to fote me falle;
Lordlich lif led I,
no lord lyuynde me i-liche,
No duk ne dred I,
for I regne in ry&yogh;th as a riche.’
Of riche þenkeþ, rewþe is to rede and roune,
Þat sitten on that semeli sete and seþþe wiþ sorwe þoruout sout;
And I beheld on hadde an heued hor als horhowne,
Al blok was his ble, in bitere bales browth.
His diademe of dyamans droppede a-doun,
His weyes were a-weyward, wroþliche iwrout,
Tynt was his tresor, tente, tour and toun,
Nedful and nawthi, naked and nawth,
I-nome;
at gome I grette wiþ griþ,
A word he warp, and wepte wiþ,
Hou he was crouned kyng in kiþ,
And caytif be-come.
‘Becomen a caytif, acast
Kynges king couþe me calle,
Fram frendes falle,
lond, luþe, litel, lo! last,
Last, litel, lordene, lif
fikel is, fortune nou fer fro,
Here wel, here wo,
here knyth, her kyng, her caytif.’
A caytif he was be-come, and kenned on care,
He myste many merþes, and meche maistri;
&YOGH;eth I say, soriere sikyng ful sare,
A bare body in a bed, a bere ibrouth him by
A duk drawe to þe deþ, wiþ drouping and dare.
